title: Sprint 2: Mirror — Orientation
description: Before setting your Sprint 2 goals, read through each section below to learn what this sprint is about and how it works. Then answer the questions to confirm your understanding.

settings.skipNudgeMessage: This question helps you understand Sprint 2 expectations. Are you sure you want to skip?

questions.infoBlock:
The Big Shift: From Self to Partner

In Sprint 1, you were both the designer and the stakeholder. You had complete knowledge of your own problem — no interviews needed, no guessing about requirements.

Sprint 2 changes that fundamentally. You'll be paired with a classmate and you'll solve their problem, not yours. They become your stakeholder. You'll have incomplete knowledge and will need to communicate, listen, and adapt your design based on what you learn about their needs.

Your partner will also be working on understanding your problem — it goes both ways.
questions.prompt: What is the fundamental change in Sprint 2?
options: You work on a harder version of the same problem
You work with a partner — solving their problem, not yours
You switch from coding to design only
You work alone but on a problem assigned by the instructor
questions.hint: Think about who the 'stakeholder' is in Sprint 2 — whose problem are you solving?
questions.explanation: In Sprint 2, you'll be paired with a classmate. You'll solve their problem and they'll help you understand yours from a new perspective. The hardest part isn't building — it's truly understanding someone else's problem.

questions.infoBlock:
Why "Mirror"?

In Sprint 1, your design thinking was internal — only you needed to understand it. You knew your own friction, your own constraints, your own motivation.

In Sprint 2, you need to make all of that visible to someone else. Your documentation, your rationale, your communication — these become the interface through which your partner understands the problem.

Your partner is your mirror: they reflect back whether your thinking is actually clear or just clear to you. If they can't understand your problem from your description, the design will fail — no matter how good the code is.
options: You copy your partner's work
You make your thinking visible to your partner — what was internal becomes external
You reflect on Sprint 1 for the entire sprint
Your partner builds an identical version of your project
questions.hint: The sprint concept is 'Interface' — what stays internal vs. what becomes visible.
questions.explanation: In Sprint 1, your design thinking was internal — only you needed to understand it. In Sprint 2, you need to make your thinking visible to someone else through documentation, rationale, and communication. Your partner is your mirror, reflecting back whether you truly understand their problem.

questions.infoBlock:
How Sprint 2 Grading Works

Sprint 2 has four grading components:

  • Goals (20%) — Individual. Your personal sprint goals.
  • Reflections (20%) — Group-averaged. Both you and your partner contribute; the average score applies to both.
  • Check-ins (20%) — Group-averaged. Discovery documentation, design rationale, and feedback activities shared with your partner.
  • Demo (40%) — Individual. Your Human Value Statement, judged by your partner.

This means 40% of your grade depends on mutual engagement. You need each other to succeed.
questions.prompt: Which parts of your Sprint 2 grade are group-averaged (meaning your partner's effort affects your grade)?
options: Goals and Demo
Reflections and Check-ins
Everything is individual
Everything is group-averaged
questions.hint: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual. What about the other 40%?
questions.explanation: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual. Reflections (20%) and Check-ins (20%) are group-averaged — your partner's participation matters. This creates mutual accountability: you need each other to succeed.

questions.infoBlock:
Two-Part Goal Setting

Unlike Sprint 1 where you set goals all at once, Sprint 2 splits goal setting into two parts:

  • Part I — Preparation (due Mon, Feb 16): Before you meet your partner. Reflect on your problem-solving skills, draft interview questions you'll use, and set a personal growth goal.
  • Part II — Partner Goals (due Thu, Feb 20): After meeting your partner in class on Wednesday. Now that you know their actual problem, set specific goals for solving it.

This split exists because you can't set meaningful goals for solving someone's problem before you've met them. Part I prepares you; Part II grounds you in reality.
questions.prompt: Why is Goal Setting split into Part I (before meeting your partner) and Part II (after meeting them)?
options: To give you more time to finish
Part I prepares you for the conversation; Part II sets real goals based on what you actually learned about your partner's problem
Part I is graded and Part II is optional
They cover different subjects entirely
questions.hint: You can't set specific goals for solving someone's problem if you haven't met them yet.
questions.explanation: Part I (due Feb 16) helps you prepare — reflecting on problem-solving skills and drafting interview questions. Part II (due Feb 20) happens after you meet your partner in class on Wednesday — now you can set specific goals based on their actual problem, not assumptions.

questions.infoBlock:
What Happens Each Week

  • Week 5: Sprint 1 Demo wraps up. Bridge Reflection + two-part Goal Setting to prepare for and then meet your partner.
  • Week 6: Discovery — understand your partner's problem deeply. Document assumptions, learn their domain, create discovery documentation.
  • Week 7: Build — create a prototype informed by what you learned. Document your design rationale and get partner feedback.
  • Week 8: Human Value Statement — articulate what YOUR human contribution was beyond what AI could do. Your partner evaluates the value.
questions.prompt: Match each week with its main focus area:
questions.hint: Sprint 2 builds from understanding → learning → building → demonstrating value.
questions.explanation: Sprint 2 follows a deliberate progression: set goals and prepare (Week 5), discover and learn about your partner's domain (Week 6), build a prototype informed by their perspective (Week 7), then articulate the human value you created (Week 8).

questions.prompt: The biggest challenge in Sprint 2 isn't technical — it's understanding someone else's problem deeply enough to solve it well. What do you think will be hardest about designing a solution for someone else instead of yourself?
questions.placeholder: Consider: assumptions you might make, what you can't know without asking, how communication affects design...

questions.infoBlock:
The Sprint 2 Demo: Human Value Statement

In Sprint 1, you demonstrated your own growth to yourself. Sprint 2's demo is fundamentally different.

The Human Value Statement asks: what did YOU contribute that AI couldn't? You built a solution for your partner's problem — but which parts required genuine human understanding? Empathy? Context that no model could have?

And here's the key: your partner — the person whose problem you solved — judges the value. They know if you truly understood their needs or just went through the motions.
questions.prompt: What makes the Sprint 2 demo (Human Value Statement) different from Sprint 1's demo?
options: It's longer
You must articulate what YOUR human contribution was beyond what AI could do — and your partner judges the value
You present it to the instructor instead of a partner
It's about code quality rather than problem-solving
questions.hint: Think about who evaluates your work and what 'value' means when solving someone else's problem.
questions.explanation: The Human Value Statement asks: what did YOU contribute that AI couldn't? Your partner — the person whose problem you solved — evaluates whether you truly understood their needs. This is the ultimate test of whether you made your thinking visible and genuinely helpful.
